q1.question: Does it modify my code?
q1.answer: No. It only makes empty commits that are immediately reverted. Your code and history stay intact.

q2.question: How much does it cost?
q2.answer: Nothing. GitPins is 100% free and open source. It uses your GitHub Actions minutes (very few).

q3.question: Can I stop using it?
q3.answer: Yes, no problem. Delete the gitpins-config repo or disable the workflow. No vendor lock-in.

q4.question: Does it work with private repos?
q4.answer: Yes. You can choose to include or exclude private repos in the settings.

q5.question: Is it safe for my repositories?
q5.answer: Yes. GitPins only has permissions to create empty commits. It cannot delete repositories, modify your code, or access sensitive information.

q6.question: What happens if I uninstall GitPins?
q6.answer: Nothing. Your repositories remain exactly the same. If you want, you can keep the Action running independently.

strategyInfo.title: Commit strategies
strategyInfo.intro: To keep your repos on top, GitPins needs to update the "last commit" date. This is done with empty commits that don't modify your code. There are two ways to do it:

revert.title: Commit + Revert
revert.desc: Makes an empty commit and reverts it immediately. Your history stays exactly the same, but the update date changes.

branch.title: Temporary branch
branch.desc: Creates a temporary branch, makes the commit there, merges to main and deletes the branch. More steps but cleaner result.

strategyInfo.note: Both strategies are safe and don't modify your code. The difference is only in how the commit history looks.

howItWorksPage.title: How GitPins works
howItWorksPage.subtitle: Technical explanation of how we keep your repositories ordered

problem.title: The problem
problem.p1: GitHub orders repositories on your profile by last update date. This means that every time you push to a repo, it goes to the top of your list.
problem.p2: If you have important projects you want to show first, but you work on other repositories, your highlighted projects get buried.

solution.title: The solution
solution.p1: GitPins uses a simple but effective mechanism: update the last commit date of your repositories in the order you choose.
solution.p2: This is done through empty commits that don't affect your code, and that are immediately removed from your history.

step1.title: Configure your order
step1.desc: In the GitPins dashboard, you drag and drop your repositories in the order you want. You can choose to order all your repos or just the first N.

step2.title: We create a config repository
step2.desc: When activating sync, we create a private repository called gitpins-config in your account. This contains the GitHub Action and your configuration.

step3.title: GitHub Actions runs periodically
step3.desc: Based on the frequency you configure (every 1, 6, 12, or 24 hours), the Action checks if your repos are in the correct order.

step4.title: Reorders if necessary
step4.desc: If any repository is out of order, the Action makes an empty commit to update its timestamp, restoring the desired order.

strategies.title: Commit strategies
strategies.intro: We offer two strategies to keep your history clean:

revert.title: Commit + Revert
revert.desc: We make an empty commit and revert it immediately. The result is that your history stays exactly the same, but the update date changes.

branch.title: Temporary branch
branch.desc: We create a temporary branch, make the commit, merge to main, and delete the branch. Cleaner but slightly more complex.

actionCode.title: The GitHub Action
actionCode.intro: We're 100% transparent. When you activate sync, a GitHub Action is created in your config repository that you can review, modify, or audit whenever you want.

steps.step1: Reads your configuration and list of repos to order
steps.step2: For each repository (in reverse order so the first one ends up most recent):
steps.step2b: Creates an empty commit using the GitHub API
steps.step2c: Reverts it immediately (or uses temporary branch)
steps.step3: Waits 1 second between repos to avoid API throttling
steps.step4: Reports the result in the Action logs

actionCode.codeLocation: The code is in .github/workflows/maintain-order.yml inside your config repository.

security.title: Security and permissions
security.permissionsTitle: Exact permissions of our GitHub App
security.permissionsIntro: Our application requests the minimum necessary permissions. This is exactly what we can and CANNOT do:

cannotDo.title: What we CANNOT do:
cannotDo.item1: NEVER delete repositories - We don't have that permission
cannotDo.item2: Modify, read, or delete your source code
cannotDo.item3: Access your secrets or environment variables
cannotDo.item5: Access Issues, PRs, Wikis, or Discussions

security.technicalNote: Technical note: GitHub Apps permissions are granular and verifiable. You can review exactly what permissions GitPins has installed on your account from

noCodeStorage.title: We don't store your code
noCodeStorage.desc: We only save the order of your repositories and your configuration. We never access the content of your repos.

runsOnYourAccount.title: The Action runs on your account
runsOnYourAccount.desc: The GitHub Action runs on your own repository, using your Actions minutes. You have full control.

canDisable.title: You can disable it anytime
canDisable.desc: Simply disable the Action or delete the config repository. No lock-in.

openSource.title: Open source and auditable
openSource.desc: The GitHub Action installed on your account is visible above. You can review it line by line before activating it.

affectsCode.a: No. Empty commits don't modify any files. And by reverting them immediately, your commit history stays intact.

actionsMinutes.q: How many Actions minutes does it use?
actionsMinutes.a: Very few. Each execution takes less than 1 minute. With the default frequency (every 6 hours), you'll use approximately 120 minutes per month, well below GitHub's free limit (2000 min/month).

privateRepos.q: Does it work with private repositories?
privateRepos.a: Yes. You can choose to include or exclude private repositories in the configuration. Note that private repos also consume Actions minutes (at double the rate on the free plan).

whatIfPush.q: What if I push to a repo?
whatIfPush.a: On the next Action run, it will detect the order changed and automatically restore it to the order you configured.

canPause.a: Yes. In settings you can disable automatic sync without losing your configuration. You can also disable the workflow directly on GitHub.

howItWorks.title: How GitPins Works - Full Transparency
howItWorks.intro: GitPins modifies the update dates of your repositories through empty commits. It's important that you understand exactly what it does:

step1.title: Empty Commits
step1.desc: GitPins creates commits that contain no code changes. These commits only update the "last commit" date of the repository.

step2.title: Automatic Reversion
step2.desc: Immediately after the empty commit, another commit is created that reverts it. Your git history technically has 2 additional commits, but no code changes.

step3.title: GitHub Actions
step3.desc: The entire process runs via a GitHub Action in your own account. The Action runs with your credentials and permissions.

risks.title: Potential Risks
risks.intro: Although GitPins is designed to be safe, there are potential risks you should know about:

risk1.title: Git History
risk1.desc: Your commit history will have additional entries (commit + revert). Although the code doesn't change, the commits are visible in the history.

risk2.title: API Dependency
risk2.desc: GitPins depends on the GitHub API. Changes to the API could affect the service's functionality.

risk3.title: Permissions
risk3.desc: The GitHub App requires write permissions on your repositories to create commits. Review the permissions carefully.

risk4.title: Actions Minutes
risk4.desc: The GitHub Action consumes minutes from your account. Private repos consume double the minutes.

noDelete.title: GitPins CANNOT Delete Your Repositories
noDelete.p1: It's important to clarify that GitPins does NOT have permissions to delete repositories. The GitHub App requests only the minimum necessary permissions:
noDelete.cannotDo1: Delete repositories - We don't have that permission
noDelete.cannotDo2: Read, modify, or delete your source code
noDelete.cannotDo5: Access Issues, Pull Requests, or Wikis
noDelete.verify: You can verify the exact permissions at any time from
